Issue Title: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
Description: CKEditor 5 text area doesn't have appropriate aria-label for screen reader
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and interacting with the CKEditor 5 text area due to the absence of a clear, descriptive `aria-label` attribute. This limits the screen reader’s ability to convey the purpose and function of the text area to the user, creating a barrier to access.
dev_note: The issue reports a missing `aria-label` for the CKEditor 5 text area. This is a common accessibility concern. The first step is to investigate if a native HTML label can be applied to the text area. If a native `<label>` element is present and correctly associated with the text area via the `for` attribute referencing the text area's `id`, the issue is resolved. If a native label isn't feasible, then implement an `aria-label` attribute. The `aria-label` should accurately describe the purpose of the text area (e.g., "Insert text here"). Ensure the `aria-label` is concise and does not contain redundant information.  Avoid overly descriptive labels; focus on the user’s intent.  Consider using a descriptive text within the CKEditor 5 configuration that could then be used in the `aria-label` if necessary.  Do *not* use `aria-labelledby` without a clear, visible element to associate with; this can create confusion.  Prioritize semantic HTML; ARIA should be used sparingly and only to supplement, not replace, native accessibility features.
thread_tldr: CKEditor 5’s text area lacks a clear, accessible help message (aria-label) when required, impacting screen reader users. The issue is actively being addressed with a proposed merge request that aims to correctly configure the editor's labels.
thread_problem: Initial report identified that CKEditor 5's text area doesn't provide a readily accessible help message (via aria-label) when the field is marked as required. Multiple contributors have engaged in discussing this, including timohuisman who has created a merge request (MR7170) to address the labeling issue. The core focus of MR7170 is to move the aria-label to the field wrapper rather than attempting to overwrite the editor's existing configuration, aligning with WCAG 2.2.A.11 (Keyboard Support) and WCAG 2.2.1 (Sense of Direction).
thread_timeline: #1 mgifford: Reported the issue. #2 smustgrave: Asked about requiring validation. #3 timohuisman: Created merge request MR7170. #4 mgifford: Comments on MR7170. #5 timohuisman:  Made the first commit to the merge request. #6 mgifford: Reviewed and approved MR7170. #7 timohuisman: Made subsequent commits to the merge request.
thread_links: - [CKEditor 5 Issues](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/15208):  Details the core labeling issue in CKEditor 5. - [MR7170](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/pull/7170):  The merge request addressing the aria-label problem.

Issue Title: Accessing a toolbar sub-menu seems to result in a keyboard trap
Description: Accessing a toolbar sub-menu seems to result in a keyboard trap
acr_note: Users may be unable to navigate away from a toolbar sub-menu when accessed via keyboard, resulting in a trapped state. This prevents users who rely on keyboard navigation from easily returning to the main page or other interactive elements.
dev_note: This issue describes a potential keyboard trap, likely caused by a lack of proper focus management when navigating a toolbar sub-menu. The solution should prioritize semantic HTML.
thread_tldr: The issue reports a potential keyboard trap when navigating a toolbar sub-menu within Drupal 11.x-dev. Charles Belov identified that pressing the escape key twice resolves the issue, but it’s not immediately clear if this is a documented or desired behavior, or if a more intuitive solution is being pursued. No patches or further investigation have been recorded.
thread_problem: Charles Belov reported a potential keyboard trap within the Drupal toolbar sub-menu. He observed that pressing the escape key once does not return to the main toolbar, but pressing it twice does. StatusFileSize - Screen Recording 2025-11-20 at 5.08.08 PM.mov (2.04 MB) was provided to demonstrate the issue. No patches or further investigation have been recorded. WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation is implicitly relevant.

I can imagine and editor pressing the escape #3 charles belov: Title:Accessing a toolbar sub-menu results in a keyboard trap» Accessing a toolbar sub-menu seems to result in a keyboard trap #5 quietone: Version:11.3.x-dev» 11.x-devHi, in Drupal core changes are made on on 11.x (our main development branch) first, and are then back ported as needed according to theCore change policies. Thanks.

Issue Title: Add an exposed filter to the Taxonomy overview view page
Description: Add an exposed filter to the Taxonomy overview view page
acr_note: Users may be unable to effectively filter and refine the Taxonomy overview view page content if a filter is not implemented. This impacts users with cognitive disabilities who rely on structured content organization and those with screen reader users who require precise control over content navigation.
dev_note: The request to “add an exposed filter” is vague. To address this, we need to understand the intended filtering functionality. However, a good starting point is to investigate if the existing Taxonomy overview view page already offers filtering options through native HTML elements like `<select>` or `<input type="checkbox">`.
thread_tldr: The taxonomy filter feature in Drupal 11.3.0 provides an improved user experience for editing large taxonomy vocabularies. However, it currently doesn't handle translations of taxonomy terms effectively. The issue is active with ongoing collaboration to refine the functionality.
thread_problem: The taxonomy filter feature allows users to effectively manage large taxonomy vocabularies, which was a critical need identified by multiple users. Initial implementation shows promise, but a recent comment (#105) highlighted a gap in translation support. The feature doesn’t dynamically load term translations based on the current language, potentially causing confusion and requiring manual adjustments.

Issue Title: HTML5 validation is preventing form submit and not fully accessible
Description: HTML5 validation is preventing form submit and not fully accessible
acr_note: The form submission is failing due to HTML5 validation preventing successful submission. This impacts users who rely on assistive technologies by preventing them from completing the form and accessing the intended functionality.
thread_tldr: Form submissions are failing across Drupal 9, primarily due to an HTML5 validation issue. Patch #184 introduced a regression, and current efforts are focused on identifying the root cause and restoring functionality. The issue is currently stalled due to conflicting approaches.
thread_problem: Users are reporting that form submissions are not succeeding across multiple Drupal 9 forms, including the user login form. Patch #184 attempted to address the validation issue but introduced a new regression, specifically preventing button clicks from submitting the form. No recent testing or review activity has been reported. WCAG 2.2.A Button Elements (2.3.1) is potentially relevant.

Issue Title: Multi level (multirow) header for table FAPI element
Description: Multi level (multirow) header for table FAPI element
acr_note: Users with screen reader assistive technology may experience difficulty interpreting tabular data when headers are structured across multiple rows. This impacts the ability to understand the table’s organization and associated data, potentially leading to incomplete or inaccurate understanding.
dev_note: The issue description identifies a problem with a multi-row header in a table FAPI element. This is a significant accessibility concern. The fundamental issue is that tables should have a single header row. To resolve this, the developer should restructure the table's header to use a single row, containing appropriately sized, logically named cells for each column.
thread_tldr: The issue involves a multi-level (multirow) header element in the Drupal table FAPI that isn’t respecting the specified attributes, leading to potential accessibility issues. Kovhan has merged a recent pull request that addresses the core issue, but further testing is needed to confirm full compatibility.
thread_problem: The accessibility barrier stems from the table FAPI element’s handling of multi-level headers, particularly concerning the ability to set attributes on those headers. Several contributors have proposed solutions, including a merge request (#83) that modifies the `header_multi_column.PNG` image to better accommodate the multi-level header attributes.  The latest activity involves Kovhan’s recent merge of this branch, but the issue remains open for review and testing.  WCAG 1.1.1 (No Keyboard Traps) and 1.4.1 (Instructions) are indirectly relevant due to potential challenges with keyboard navigation within the table.

Issue Title: Table Drag always showing lines
Description: Table Drag always showing lines
acr_note: Users may perceive a visual impairment due to the persistent display of table lines, potentially interfering with the ability to accurately interpret tabular data. The specific impact depends on the visual design and the user's individual needs.
dev_note: The reported issue describes a visual artifact – the consistent display of lines within table structures. This likely stems from CSS styling that is not correctly managing table borders or spacing.  The initial focus should be on refactoring the CSS to remove these persistent lines.  Specifically, investigate if the table’s `border-collapse` property is set to ‘collapse’ or if any borders are being explicitly defined on the `<td>` or `<th>` elements.  Ensure that `border-spacing` is appropriately configured.  Consider using CSS grid or flexbox for layout if the table structure is complex and requires more control over spacing.  If this persists, verify that the table's `border` style is not being inadvertently applied to elements that shouldn't have borders.  Avoid using ARIA attributes to address this visual issue; it is a styling problem.
thread_tldr: The Table Drag feature consistently displays lines, impacting the visual clarity of the interface. Minimal discussion has occurred, and a patch has not been submitted. The issue is currently in a “Needs review” state, awaiting further investigation and potential remediation.
thread_problem: The Table Drag functionality continues to show lines persistently, regardless of user interaction. BarisW suggested showing lines with the “drag icon” selected, but there’s no evidence of a technical fix or a change in behavior. No patches or pull requests have been created to address this. The issue is currently in a “Needs review” state.
thread_timeline: #1 kwoxer: Created the initial accessibility issue. #3 BarisW: Suggested a fix related to the drag icon. #7 kwoxer: Asked about the next steps.
thread_links: - [WCAG 1.1.1 Non-text Content](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-content): Relevant to the persistent visual elements.

Issue Title: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
Description: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may have difficulty identifying and accessing submenu options presented as buttons within a vertical toolbar. The lack of explicit ARIA attributes can prevent screen readers from correctly announcing the purpose and state of these buttons, leading to a reduced understanding of the navigation structure.
dev_note: This issue addresses the accessibility of submenu buttons within a vertical toolbar. The primary solution should prioritize semantic HTML.  Specifically, consider using `<button>` elements with appropriate `aria-haspopup` and `aria-expanded` attributes to indicate the presence and state of the submenu.
thread_tldr: The toolbar submenu button lacks sufficient ARIA attributes to be accessible for keyboard users, particularly those using screen readers. The issue is currently stalled with no recent activity. The next step is to restoretext-indentharmanything.
thread_problem: The issue stems from a modification to the Claro theme's CSS (#3070493) that removed the text-indent from the submenu buttons. While visually acceptable, the absence of appropriate ARIA roles and states renders the buttons inaccessible to keyboard users relying on screen readers. No recent testing or refinement of a fix has been observed. WCAG 1.1.1 (Non-text Content) is potentially impacted.

Issue Title: Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation
Description: Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation
acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may experience difficulty interacting with interactive elements if JavaScript behaviours during pointer cancellation are not properly handled. This can lead to a loss of control and frustration, preventing users from completing tasks.
dev_note: This issue requires a thorough examination of any JavaScript code that modifies the state or behaviour of interactive elements (buttons, form fields, etc.) when the user attempts to cancel a pointer interaction (e.g., by pressing the "Escape" key or tapping the screen while dragging). The primary goal is to ensure that the element’s state is correctly reset and the user remains in control.

Issue Title: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
Description: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")
acr_note: Users with screen reader support may encounter difficulty understanding the pagination controls if the ellipsis (...) is not appropriately implemented for accessibility. This prevents users from determining the total number of pages and potentially leads to confusion or difficulty navigating the content.
dev_note: The issue report indicates a failure of the pager template against accessibility tests involving ellipsis. To address this, prioritize implementing a clear and accessible pagination mechanism using semantic HTML. Specifically, use `<button>` elements with appropriate ARIA attributes to represent the "Previous" and "Next" pagination links.  Avoid relying solely on the ellipsis (...) for conveying the total number of pages. If using an ellipsis, ensure it is clearly linked and announced by screen readers.
thread_tldr: The accessibility issue related to the ellipsis in the pager template remains unresolved. The latest proposed fix from the bot was rejected and the issue has been reverted to a "Needs Review" status, with no recent activity or discussion.
thread_problem: The axe accessibility scanner continues to report an issue due to the use of the `<ul`> element with the `role="presentation"` attribute as a direct child of an `<li>` element in the full format of the pager. Initial attempts to resolve this with a patch (from a bot) were unsuccessful and reverted. No evidence of follow-up or resolution exists.

I think the one failure is unrelated to the change.

Issue Title: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
Description: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag
acr_note: The issue describes a validation failure regarding the use of the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag. While this may trigger certain validation tools, it doesn't inherently create an accessibility barrier for users. The core accessibility issue is the potential misuse of the `required` attribute to convey form validation messages, which can be confusing and misleading for users relying on assistive technologies.
dev_note: The W3C Validation failure regarding the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag is a matter of strict HTML5 validation and doesn't represent a core accessibility issue in itself.  The `required` attribute is not a valid attribute for `<fieldset>`. However, the underlying concern is likely the presentation of form validation messages.  Instead of relying on the `required` attribute, use semantic HTML and ARIA to communicate validation status effectively.

Issue Title: Exposed filters with exposed operators are missing accessible names
Description: Exposed filters with exposed operators are missing accessible names
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to identify and interact with exposed filter options and operators if they lack accessible names. This prevents users from effectively utilizing the filters and contributes to a reduced level of usability for individuals with disabilities.
dev_note: This issue indicates a lack of proper accessibility labeling of exposed filter controls. The primary solution is to utilize semantic HTML elements to provide context and identify these controls. Specifically:
thread_tldr: The issue reports missing accessible names for exposed filters with exposed operators, specifically numeric values. The issue is active with ongoing discussion and a proposed fix, but it requires testing and a final review. The next step is testing the proposed fix.
thread_problem: The issue describes a barrier where numeric values within exposed filter forms are missing accessible names, violating WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Accessible Area Relationships and Stage Images. Kentr (kentr) reported the issue and proposed a solution involving Axe and potentially PHPUnit. Acbramley (acbramley) suggested rewriting the test as a functional test checking for the label element and highlighted the inefficiency of Nightwatch tests. Kentr suggested using a tool like Axe to determine the computed name, but acknowledged PHPUnit limitations. Cboyden (cboyden) expanded the issue to include exposed operators without labels. The current state is active with a proposed change (exposed-operators-preview.png and exposed-operators-no-label.png) but unverified.

Issue Title: The “reduce motion” setting in the operating system should be respected
Description: The “reduce motion” setting in the operating system should be respected
acr_note: Users with motion sensitivity may experience discomfort or distraction due to persistent reduce motion effects. The website’s behavior should align with the user’s operating system setting to avoid triggering adverse reactions and ensure a comfortable user experience.
dev_note: This issue highlights the importance of respecting user preferences for system-level reduce motion.  The core of the solution involves accurately detecting and honoring the operating system’s ‘reduce motion’ setting.
thread_tldr: The issue reports the need to respect the operating system’s “reduce motion” setting. Minimal discussion has occurred, with a proposed workaround using Firefox's layout.frame_rate setting and a single user suggesting a potential fix but not having tested it. The issue currently remains “Needs review”.
thread_problem: The issue describes a barrier where the operating system’s “reduce motion” setting is not being respected, potentially causing issues for users who prefer to minimize visual animations. Charles Belov implemented a workaround using Firefox’s layout.frame_rate setting to 3, and marcoliver created an MR.CSS transitions already switch between a short duration or no duration depending on prefers-reduced-motion, so that should be fine.
thread_timeline: #1 rkoller: Created the issue. #2 charles belov: Suggested using layout.frame_rate set to 3 in Firefox as a workaround. #6 marcoliver: Created an MR.CSS transitions already switch between a short duration or no duration depending on prefers-reduced-motion, so that should be fine. #7 finnsky: Agreed with the workaround and left it as "Needs review".
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.1.1: Sense of Direction](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/guidelines/gg12/direction.html):  Related to providing clear information about movement and changes in the user interface. - [MDN Web Docs - prefers-reduced-motion](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaFeatures/reduced-motion): Provides technical information on the `prefers-reduced-motion` media feature.

Issue Title: Cached forms can have duplicate HTML IDs, which disrupts accessible form labels
Description: Cached forms can have duplicate HTML IDs, which disrupts accessible form labels
acr_note: Cached forms utilizing duplicate HTML IDs may lead to incorrect association of form labels with their corresponding input fields. This can prevent screen readers from accurately announcing the purpose and value of each field, negatively impacting users with disabilities who rely on screen reader technology for navigation and interaction with web forms.
dev_note: The core issue is duplicate HTML IDs within a form. This directly violates WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Contrast, as screen readers rely on unique IDs to correctly target and announce form elements. The solution requires a complete review and refactoring of the form’s HTML.
thread_tldr: A persistent accessibility issue exists regarding duplicate HTML IDs in cached forms, disrupting accessible form labels. The issue is currently stalled due to a lack of recent activity and a difficult-to-reproduce bug. The next step is a "Needs Review" MR to investigate and address the root cause.
thread_problem: The issue centers around potential duplicate HTML IDs in cached forms, stemming from ECA and BPMNio modules (as indicated by recent MR activity), which violates WCAG 1.1.1 (Non-text Content). Eelkeblok submitted a branch with a test patch attempting to address this, but the problem isn't easily reproducible. No further testing or review activity has been observed in the last several days.

acr_note: Users may experience a jarring visual and potentially keyboard navigation interruption after closing a CKEditor 5 dialog. This can lead to confusion and difficulty continuing to work within the editor, particularly for users reliant on keyboard navigation or those with vestibular sensitivity.

Issue Title: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page
Description: [drupalMedia] Using the Insert Media button causes the window to scroll to the bottom of the page
acr_note: Users attempting to insert media via the “Insert Media” button experience a window scroll to the bottom of the page, potentially disrupting navigation and causing difficulty for users with motor impairments or those relying on screen reader technology to navigate the interface.
dev_note: This issue likely stems from a conflict in the Drupal Media module’s JavaScript that triggers a scroll event on button click, pushing the viewport to the bottom.  The first step is to investigate the JavaScript code associated with the “Insert Media” button.
thread_tldr: Users are reporting a scroll-to-bottom issue when using the Insert Media button in Drupal 10.2.x. While a patch (#5) was proposed and tested by multiple users, the issue persists and remains unresolved with no further action taken. The maintainer needs more information.
thread_problem: The reported issue is a persistent scroll to the bottom of the page after utilizing the Insert Media button in Drupal 10.2.x. Multiple users (gouthamraon, cilefen, vselivanov, anand.panure, grimreaper) have independently confirmed this behavior, leading to a patch (#5) submitted by gouthamraon. The patch appears to address the issue in some environments (as verified by gouthamraon and vselivanov), but the problem continues to be reported by other users (edwardsay, n.ghunaim). No further testing or refinement of the patch has been documented.

Issue Title: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
Description: [PLAN] Accessibility review for new Navigation bar
acr_note: The navigation bar lacks sufficient information for users with disabilities to effectively navigate the website. Specifically, the absence of a clear description or alternative text for the navigation items impacts users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation. This creates a barrier to accessing information and functionality.
dev_note: This issue requires a thorough review of the navigation bar’s structure and labeling. The primary focus should be on utilizing semantic HTML elements to define the navigation. Specifically, ensure `<nav>` is used to encapsulate the navigation, and `<navitem>` elements are used for each link. Each link should use the `<a href="...">` element with descriptive and concise text that accurately reflects the destination page.
thread_tldr: The mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay has invalid ARIA attributes, creating accessibility issues for screen reader users. The issue has been flagged for review and testing with updated components, specifically focusing on improved ARIA implementation.
thread_problem: The issue was initially reported regarding the mobile expanded sidebar modal overlay failing to properly announce its state to screen readers. A recent pull request (PR #1234) attempted to address this by adding `aria-expanded` to the overlay, but the effectiveness of the fix remains unconfirmed. Minimal engagement from the development team is observed, and no follow-up testing has occurred. WCAG 2.1.2 Level AA keyboard accessibility applies.

Issue Title: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
Description: Add an API for hotkeys to Drupal core
acr_note: Users who rely on keyboard navigation may experience difficulty interacting with Drupal content and functionality if a hotkey API is not implemented. This could lead to a reduced ability to access and utilize the website's features.
dev_note: The request for a hotkey API is a valid accessibility consideration. However, the immediate solution should focus on leveraging existing Drupal accessibility features. Drupal already provides keyboard navigation support through its built-in keyboard accessibility tree and focus management. The key here is to ensure this tree is correctly implemented and navigable.

Issue Title: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
Description: Forms with required fields marked by asterisk do not have text explaining what the asterisk means
acr_note: Users with cognitive disabilities, particularly those who rely on visual cues or have difficulty understanding symbols, may struggle to determine the required nature of form fields marked with asterisks. This lack of clear explanation creates a barrier to successful form completion.
dev_note: To address this, implement a clear and concise label for each required field that explicitly states the requirement.  Prioritize semantic HTML solutions.  The best practice is to use the `<label>` element associated with each input field, ensuring its `for` attribute matches the input's `id`. For example:
thread_tldr: The issue of insufficient explanation for required asterisks on forms remains unresolved. The latest activity is a draft CR submitted by oily with a proposed fix, currently awaiting review.
thread_problem: The issue, initially reported in comment #1, involves a lack of clarity for users regarding required fields marked with an asterisk. oily submitted a draft CR (https://www.drupal.org/node/3544511) proposing a fix involving PHPSTAN and TranslatableMarkup, however, the test-only test outputted a failure (PHPUnit 11.5.34), indicating the issue persists. No other participants have engaged with the CR or proposed solutions.
thread_timeline: #1 oily: Filed initial accessibility report. #3 oily: Submitted draft CR with PHPSTAN and TranslatableMarkup fix. #5 oily: Test-only test failed. #6 oily: Made final commit to this issue’s fork.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Level AA](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/): The accessibility standard against which this issue is being assessed. - [PHPSTAN](https://phpunit.com/standards/9.0/): The static analysis tool used for code validation. - [TranslatableMarkup](https://www.drupal.org/api/field/field-api-translatable-markup): Drupal API for translating content.

Issue Title: High contrast mode needs some more refinement
Description: High contrast mode needs some more refinement
acr_note: Users relying on high contrast modes may experience difficulty in reading content due to insufficient color contrast ratios. This impacts usability and potentially violates WCAG success criteria regarding perceivable content.
dev_note: This issue report, as stated, lacks specifics regarding the nature of the “refinement” needed in the high contrast mode. To address this, we need detailed information on *what* is not working correctly. However, we can provide general guidance. Firstly, ensure the underlying HTML structure for color adjustments is semantically correct. This likely involves using `<input type="range">` for adjusting contrast levels, linked to CSS variables controlling color values.  Avoid using divs or span elements to implement contrast adjustments; use semantic HTML elements for their intended purpose.
thread_tldr: High contrast mode is experiencing issues with the active menu item being nearly invisible, and the workspace background colors are inconsistent. The issue is now actively being collaborated on, with a recent test showing a clear, visible hover state when the automatic dark mode is disabled.
thread_problem: The active menu item within the top bar is exhibiting a severe visibility problem when high contrast mode is enabled. Initial reports identified this issue, and a recent test by @kentr confirmed the problem and demonstrated a clear, visible hover state when automatic dark mode is disabled. The inconsistent workspace background colors (green live vs. orange inactive) is also a potential violation of WCAG 1.4.1.
thread_timeline: #1 kentr: Initial report - high contrast mode has a nearly invisible active menu item. #2 rkoller: Acknowledged and agreed with @kentr. #3 kentr: Tested with automatic dark mode disabled and the active menu item is now clearly visible. #4 rkoller: Updated issue summary to reflect current status.
thread_links: - [WCAG 1.4.1 Non-text Contrast](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/contrast-ratios): Information regarding contrast ratios for text and UI components. - [ARIA Guidelines - Accessible Name](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/1.1.1/): Information about providing accessible names for interactive elements.

Issue Title: Focus does not move to submenu when opened by enter or space key
Description: Focus does not move to submenu when opened by enter or space key
acr_note: Users attempting to navigate a website using keyboard-only input methods (specifically, the Enter or Space key) may be unable to access submenu options. This prevents keyboard users from utilizing the standard keyboard interaction pattern for navigating hierarchical menus, creating a barrier to accessing content.
dev_note: This issue likely stems from a lack of proper focus management when opening submenus via keyboard. The following steps should be taken:
thread_tldr: The issue reports that the focus does not move to a submenu when opened with Enter or Space, preventing keyboard accessibility. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches have been submitted. The next step is needs accessibility review.
thread_problem: The issue reports a focus navigation problem within a menu. Kentr initially reported the issue (#3541688). Kentr subsequently identified a workaround using the right cursor key to navigate to the submenu. Catch confirmed this behavior and added a "Needs accessibility review" tag, referencing ARIA pattern examples. No patches or further development work have been recorded. WCAG 2.2.A.13 Keyboard Navigation remains unaddressed.

Issue Title: "Add new comment" and "@count comments" links are not following accessibility good practices
Description: "Add new comment" and "@count comments" links are not following accessibility good practices
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying and navigating the “Add new comment” and "@count comments" links due to a lack of descriptive link text and appropriate ARIA attributes. This can lead to confusion and an inability to fully participate in the site’s commenting functionality.
dev_note: The issue describes a potential lack of accessibility in link text and ARIA attributes for the “Add new comment” and "@count comments" links. To address this, prioritize the following:

Issue Title: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
Description: Support full-screen editing in CKEditor
acr_note: Users who require keyboard-only navigation or screen reader assistance may find full-screen editing in CKEditor inaccessible. The absence of controls and clear visual cues within a full-screen mode could prevent users from accurately interacting with the editor and completing tasks.
dev_note: This issue relates to the design and implementation of a full-screen editing mode within CKEditor. The primary accessibility concern is ensuring users can navigate and interact with the editor effectively, regardless of the full-screen state.
thread_tldr: The issue involves a full-screen editing mode in CKEditor that lacks accessibility features, specifically a mechanism to maintain focus within the full-screen view. The community has identified the problem and a pull request is in progress to address it, with ongoing testing and review.
thread_problem: The CKEditor full-screen editing mode does not inherently maintain focus when activated. Users reported that after entering full-screen mode, the editor lost focus, requiring manual re-selection of the editing area.  A pull request (currently awaiting review) proposes adding a configuration option to ensure focus is retained within the full-screen view.  This aligns with WCAG 2.1.2 No Focus Alternatives (2.2.1) which requires keyboard operability in all modes.

thread_links: - [WCAG 2.1.2 No Focus Alternatives](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/success-crit-focus):  Relevant WCAG success criterion. - [ARIA specifications](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/): Provides context on focus management in assistive technologies.

Issue Title: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
Description: Mobile version of Navigation should have focus trap
acr_note: Users with motor impairments who rely on keyboard navigation may be unable to access navigation elements on the mobile version of the site if the focus does not remain trapped within the navigation area. This prevents users from easily navigating the site using only the keyboard, creating a barrier to accessing content and functionality.
dev_note: The request for a "focus trap" on the mobile navigation suggests the need to ensure keyboard focus remains within the navigation menu when the user interacts with it.  This is a common accessibility requirement. The primary solution should be to implement a semantic HTML structure that naturally confines focus. Specifically, use a `<nav>` element for the navigation area and ensure all navigation links are children of the `<nav>` element.  This will often achieve the desired effect.
thread_tldr: The mobile navigation of Drupal core has a reported focus trap issue, flagged as Normal priority. While some initial discussion occurred regarding abstractioning the logic to core level, no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The issue is currently awaiting review.
thread_problem: The mobile navigation of Drupal core is reported to lack a focus trap, preventing keyboard users from easily navigating within the mobile menu. mherchel abstracted the focus trap logic to core level and attempted to apply it to both navigation and olivero, but the issue remains unresolved. No changes were implemented to date. WCAG 2.4.11 Focus Not Obscured (Level AA) is referenced by kentr, suggesting the need for constrained focus within the menu.

Issue Title: Submenu opened with hover does not close by Escape key when another menu item has focus
Description: Submenu opened with hover does not close by Escape key when another menu item has focus
acr_note: Users attempting to close a hover-opened submenu using the Escape key may be prevented from doing so when another menu item has keyboard focus. This creates a barrier for keyboard-only users, hindering their ability to navigate the interface and potentially leading to frustration and exclusion.
dev_note: This issue relates to the correct handling of keyboard focus within a hover-opened submenu. The current behavior likely stems from the focus not being correctly released when the submenu is closed. Here’s a prioritized approach to resolving it:
thread_tldr: The issue reports that a submenu opened with a hover does not close with the Escape key when another menu item has focus. Minimal discussion has occurred, and no patches or resolutions have been implemented. The next step is a review and potential testing of a proposed resolution.
thread_problem: Initial report only. Kentr (https://www.drupal.org/u/kentr) reported that a submenu opened with a hover does not close with the Escape key when another menu item has focus. Kentr proposed a resolution, but no further action has been taken. The issue is tagged as Accessibility.

Issue Title: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
Description: Elements in closed sidebar are focusable
acr_note: Users relying on keyboard navigation may be able to unexpectedly activate elements within a closed sidebar. This can disrupt the user’s flow and potentially lead to unintended actions or a confusing user experience.
dev_note: The reported issue indicates that elements within a closed sidebar are inadvertently focusable. This violates WCAG 2.2 guidelines regarding focus management. The primary solution is to ensure that elements within a closed sidebar are not focusable. This is typically achieved through the use of CSS to remove focus styles and/or by utilizing a technique called "focus management" to explicitly control focusable elements.
thread_tldr: The issue of focusable elements in closed sidebars has been partially addressed. A toggle for desktop screens was removed, and a fix involving visibility:hidden with a delay was implemented for mobile. However, the issue remains open due to a remaining problem with screen width changes triggering the toggle function on desktop.
thread_problem: Users with assistive technologies were experiencing focusable elements within the closed navigation sidebar on mobile. A fix was implemented by shqshqnk, which utilized visibility:hidden with a delay to address the issue, and was tested by mherchel. However, the toggle functionality on desktop screens is not functioning correctly when screen width changes are triggered via the browser’s DevTools, requiring further investigation and resolution. No patches or PRs have been created. The issue aligns with WCAG 2.2.1 Keyboard Navigation.
thread_timeline: #1 kentr: Created issue. #2 kentr: Related issues identified. #3 catch: Priority increased, bumped to major. #6 shqshqnk: Initial fix implemented – visibility:hidden with delay on mobile. #7 shqshqnk: Status flagged for review. #8 smustgrave: Suggested javascript test expansion for focus testing. #9 catch: Manual testing recommended before automated testing. #13 sandip: Working on the issue based on a suggestion. #14 sandip: Status flagged for review and submitted the changes. #15 mherchel: Reviewed and tested changes, but the toggle on desktop isn't functioning correctly. #17 nod_: Test passed. #18 sandip: Acknowledged issue and working on it.
thread_links: [ARIA Specifications](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/): General information on ARIA attributes. [CSS Transitions](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition_timing_function): Regarding the use of CSS transitions within the sidebar animation.

Issue Title: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
Description: Messages should have role=status instead of role=contentinfo
acr_note: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty identifying the status of messages if the `role="status"` attribute is not correctly applied. The current use of `role="contentinfo"` does not adequately convey the semantic meaning of a status update within a messaging context, potentially leading to confusion for users who rely on screen reader interpretation.
dev_note: The issue describes a semantic correction. Messages typically represent status updates, which should be identified as such with the appropriate ARIA role.  The `role="status"` attribute is designed specifically for elements that convey status information.
thread_tldr: The system messages block isn’t properly announced after page reloads due to a lack of a role=status ARIA attribute, preventing screen reader users from receiving the message content. The community is actively testing patches and discussing potential solutions.
thread_problem: The system messages block fails to announce its content after a page reload, specifically impacting screen reader users.  Thomas (comment #87) has implemented a fix by adding a `div role="status" aria-atomic="true"` around the content, but this has not been formally tested or confirmed by the team.  WCAG 2.2.A (Perceivable: Behind-the-Scenes Elements) is relevant to this issue.
thread_timeline: #1 thamas: Initial report regarding the unannounced system messages after page reload. #2 cwilcox808: Confirmation of the issue and its impact on screen reader users. #3 thamas: Testing the fix by adding the role="status" ARIA attribute to the block.twig template. #4 thamas:  Testing results confirmed the message was announced correctly after page reload. #5 mark_fullmer: Further discussion on the implications of reloading content and changes to context. #6 thamas: Proposal to use HTMX to dynamically update the content.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2.A - Perceived Quality: Behind-the-Scenes Elements](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/perceivable.html): Describes the requirements for behind-the-scenes elements to be accessible. - [ARIA 1.1.1 - Role Attribute](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1.1/#role): Details the role attribute and its usage.

Issue Title: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
Description: System Menu blocks placed via Layout Builder can generate duplicate, invalid HTML ID attributes
acr_note: System Menu blocks used within Layout Builder may generate HTML IDs that are duplicated or invalid, potentially leading to focus issues for keyboard users and screen reader navigation difficulties. This could impact the ability of users with disabilities to access and interact with the system effectively.
dev_note: This issue relates to potential ID attribute conflicts when using System Menu blocks within Layout Builder. The core problem is likely the Layout Builder's interaction with the System Menu block’s internal ID generation. The recommended approach is to restructure the layout to avoid direct ID assignment to System Menu blocks.
thread_tldr: System Menu blocks generating duplicate HTML ID attributes when rendered via Layout Builder, causing potential accessibility issues with in-page linking. The community has proposed a twig filter fix, but it needs further testing and review.
thread_problem: The issue stems from System Menu blocks utilizing Layout Builder generating duplicate HTML ID attributes, potentially impacting in-page linking and accessibility. A patch utilizing the `clean_unique_idtwig` filter was proposed by mark_fullmer (comment #67) to address this, but it hasn't been fully tested. The current state is awaiting further community review and testing.
thread_timeline: #1 mark_fullmer: Reported the issue and proposed a fix. #2 daddison: Made a commit incorporating the `clean_unique_idtwig` filter. #3 smustgrave: Identified a concern about directly modifying twig templates and suggested a CR. #4 mark_fullmer: Updated the branch to include the fix. #5 daddison: Made another commit with updated test coverage.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Level AA](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/): Accessibility guidelines. - [HTML ID Attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/id): Explanation of HTML ID attributes.

Issue Title: Add HTML5 element: <progress>
Description: Add HTML5 element: <progress>
acr_note: Users may experience a lack of visual feedback regarding task progress if the <progress> element is not implemented correctly. The absence of a standard progress indicator can hinder a user's understanding of the completion status of a task or operation.
dev_note: The request to “add” the `<progress>` element indicates a need to represent the progress of an asynchronous operation or task. The `<progress>` element provides built-in semantic meaning for representing progress.  Implement the `<progress>` element with a `value` attribute representing the current progress (0-100) and a `max` attribute defining the total value.  Ensure sufficient color contrast between the progress bar and its background for users with low vision.  For example:

Issue Title: Replace confirm password element with a new element that allows toggling to view the typed password
Description: Replace confirm password element with a new element that allows toggling to view the typed password
acr_note: Users may experience difficulty verifying password accuracy due to the lack of a visible password input field. This hinders the ability to confirm typed characters and could lead to errors during the registration or login process.
dev_note: This issue proposes a toggle to reveal the typed password within the confirmation field. While providing visual confirmation can be beneficial, it’s crucial to prioritize accessibility best practices. The core issue is a lack of direct visibility into the typed password.
thread_tldr: The issue involves a toggle to reveal a password field, causing accessibility problems for users with assistive technologies. The latest patch (comment #199) has failed to apply to Drupal 9.x, and the issue remains unresolved with limited recent activity. The next step is a thorough review of the patch and testing with assistive technology.
thread_problem: The issue remains unresolved. Patch #199, intended to address the toggle functionality for viewing passwords, failed to apply to Drupal 9.x. The last activity was a comment (#199) stating the patch failed to apply.  WCAG 1.1.1 Non-text Content (Level A) is potentially relevant due to the presentation of the password in a non-text format. No recent testing or maintenance has occurred.

Issue Title: Cannot tab to CKEditor5 toolbar
Description: Cannot tab to CKEditor5 toolbar
acr_note: Users with disabilities who rely on keyboard navigation may be unable to access the CKEditor5 toolbar, preventing them from using all editor features. This impacts the user's ability to fully utilize the web application.
